We as an organisation are trying to come up

The best way of doing that is to try things

There really isn’t a toolkit in how to do

Well, when you’re evaluating whole systems
change programmes

107.98.text:
there are a whole range of different challenges
that face you

110.11.text: but really the main one is that of complexity.

113.19.text:
My top tips for the evaluator really follow
from the challenge of complexity.

117.10.text:
The first is to understand that you’re in
a complex environment and that you can’t

121.30.text:
apply traditional evaluation techniques in
that environment.

124.26.text:
You must accept the complexity and do something
about it, not to wish it away.

128.45.text:
So there’s an important debate to be had
in thinking about systems change.

131.70.text:
A lot of us have used logic models as a basic
way of structuring our

136.39.text:
conceptual thinking around the evaluation
that we’re doing.

140.30.text:
The advantage of that is that is makes the
intervention clear, the outcomes clear.

145.61.text:
It gives you things that you ought to be measuring
and assessing

148.62.text: and allows you to form a judgement.

150.57.text: The downside is that it is ineluctably linear.

157.01.text:
Systems react in unanticipated ways, they
bubble, they’re turbulent, they shift.

161.46.text:
You get cliff edges that you’ll suddenly
drop off

163.96.text:
you get takeoff ramps that you suddenly take
off into

166.96.text:
and they’re very, very difficult to analyse
in a linear manner.

172.55.text:
However, that said, I would argue that in
most of the evaluations that we do

177.96.text:

186.23.text:
But they have degrees of stickiness and they

193.76.text:
Those are all things that you can evaluate
and give you some stability

198.37.text: in the thing that you’re evaluating.

One of the common traditional tools used in

203.87.text: and I think the logic model has its place

206.14.text:
I just don’t think its place is in terms

209.62.text: The logic model works off a very linear logic.

213.24.text:
If we do this, then that will result, if that

216.42.text: But that’s not the way that systems work.

220.71.text: and that’s what makes it a system.

I think what I’ve learnt is that it’s
